data.title: Crainquebille (1922)
data.meta_description: Jérôme Crainquebille, is an ageing vegetable seller who has sold groceries from his cart in in Paris for over 40 years. One day, he is harassed by a policeman who insists that he moves on. When he protests, Crainquebille is arrested, supposedly for swearing at the policeman.
data.text:
This is mostly a straightforward adaptation of Anatole France's story about a vegetable peddler who gets arrested for talking back to a cop, spends a couple of not-too-unpleasant weeks in jail, and then finds his life ruined when he gets out. It expands the story in three ways: a long prologue that introduces us to Paris in general and to the supporting characters, which is wonderful; a brief subplot with a new character who exists to give us a relatively happy ending, which is predictable but done pretty well; and some wild visual effects in the trial scenes to literalize the old man's confusion about the legal process, which clash with the style of the rest of the movie (and…

CRAINQUEBILLE (Jacques Feyder, France, 1922, 7)

Relative to my expectations I’d have to call that a bit of a disappointment (this was my most anticipated film of the festival). Feyder’s observational skills and flair for texture are typically excellent and you haven’t seen a “grumpy adult bonds with cute moppet” film done quite this way — on multiple fronts even if the end is a little pat. Not only am I also a sucker for courtroom dramas, but also a sucker for subjective surrealism. You’ve not seen many 1922 films that look like this trial scene. Feyder lays out the tracks meticulously, seemingly meandering in plotless nowhere for “too long.” But that is just laying out the characters for their…

Presented at The San Francisco Silent Film Festival 2023

Saturday, July 15, 2023 at 7:00 PM

Crainquebille

Live music by the Stephen Horne Ensemble

DirectorJacques Feyder

Cast Maurice de Féraudy, Félix Oudart, Jean Forest, Marguerite Carré

Based on a novel by Anatole France, director Feyder’s poetic masterpiece details the life of peddler Crainquebille (the magnificent Maurice de Féraudy), who, because of a ridiculous misunderstanding, is arrested. After leaving jail, his life is upended when once-faithful customers shun him. Brilliantly told with humor and compassion.

Source Information:

Crainquebille was restored by Lobster Films in 2019 with the support of the CNC (Centre National du Cinéma et de l’Image animée), from five original elements: a few fragments of the original camera negative…
